note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

note.p: Eugene Woldemar Hilgard was a chemist and geologist and is often credited as the “father of soil science” in the United States.

Born in Zweibruecken, Bavaria, on January 5, 1833, Hilgard moved with his family to the United States in 1835. His family settled in Illinois, but Hilgard suffered from poor health—in part due to malaria—and later traveled to Washington, D.C. with is brother in pursuit of a healthier climate. Once there, he met several leading scientists and began pursuing a formal education in chemistry. During a visit to the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Hilgard was encouraged to return to Europe to study analytical chemistry. In 1849, he traveled to Heidelberg to meet one of his brothers studying medicine there.

Hilgard studied in Germany and Switzerland, eventually receiving a Ph.D. in chemistry in 1853 at Heidelberg. He spent two years in Spain and Portugal, then returned to the United States and received a position as the assistant state geologist of Mississippi in 1855. He served in that position for two years before spending one year in Washington, D.C., as head of the Smithsonian Institution’s laboratory and lecturing on chemistry at the National Medical College in Washington, D.C. In 1858 he became the state geologist for Mississippi and a professor of chemistry at the University of Mississippi. He remained on the university campus during the Civil War, overseeing the use of some campus buildings as hospitals for wounded Union and Confederate soldiers.

Hilgard remained Mississippi’s state geologist until 1873, when he moved to Michigan to take a position as professor of mineralogy, geology, zoology, and botany. Two years later, he moved again, this time to California, where he became professor of agricultural chemistry at the University of California, Berkley. He remained in that position from 1875 to 1904. In California, Hilgard oversaw the state’s agricultural experiment station and conducted numerous soil studies. His publications in Mississippi and California established him as a leading expert in soil sciences.

Hilgard died on January 8, 1916. He had been married to Jesusa Alexandrina Bello—the daughter of a Spanish Army officer, who Hilgard had met in Spain during his European studies as a young man. The couple had four children. Hilgard is buried in St. Mary’s Cemetery in Oakland, California.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

note.p: Brevet Major Edward Carlisle Boynton was a U.S. Army officer, professor, author, and Superintendent of the Newburgh Water Works. Born on Feburary 1, 1824 in Windsor, Vermont, Boynton graduated from the U.S. Military Academy at West Point in New York in 1846. After graduation, he served in the Mexican-American War and the Seminole Wars in Florida, and he worked as an Assistant Professor at West Point 1848 to 1855. He taught French, Chemistry, Mineralogy, and Geology. From 1856 to September 1861, Boynton was a Professor of Chemistry, Mineralogy, and Geology at the University of Mississippi. However, his anti-Confederate sympathies led to his dismissal, at which point he returned to West Point as Adjutant and Quartermaster. Boynton remained at West Point until he resigned from the army in 1872. In the 1860s, he also wrote at least nine publications, including "A Guide to West Point and the U.S. Military Academy" (1867).

After his resignation, Boynton lived in Newburgh, New York for the rest of his life with his second wife Mary Jane Hubbard (married 1852). The two had at least four children (one son and three daughters). His first wife EIizabeth M. Webb died in 1851, just two years into the marriage. In Newburgh, he worked as Superintendant of the Newburgh Water Works and as a trustee of Washington's headquarters. Boynton died on May 13, 1893. He was buried in the Ascutney Cemetery in Windsor, Vermont.
(FindaGrave; P.T. Turnley, Twenty-Fourth Annual Reunion of the Association of the Graduates of the United States Military Academy, June 9, 1893)

div.fw: Letter from E. C. Boynton to Mississippi Governor John J. Pettus; December 17, 1860
div.p:
To His Ex John J. Pettus
Jackson Miss

On the 30th day of November, I enclosed to you the account of the State Geologist, (Dr E. W. Hilgard) due on the 30th of Sept last, which account was transferred to me on my order for the sum of of $500.00
I am anxious for fear the order & account, has not been received. Will you please inform me if this is the case

I am with much respect
E. C. Boynton
Prof of Chem
